content:
(lmk if I should move this to a different stream) Was noticing in the docs for ManuallyDropped that "Undefined Behavior" is capitalized, but it seems like in most of the other docs it is not. Attached are screenshots of how often each of the capitalizations are used in the rust repo

Screen-Shot-2021-10-18-at-8.56.51-PM.png

Screen-Shot-2021-10-18-at-8.57.09-PM.png

I was thinking about making the changes at least to the docs and the tests - what do you think? Also, is there a style guide for something like this that I am missing?
UB is not something that either British or American capitalization rules would allow to be capitalized in prose afaik.
Unless it's a section title (in which both words can be capitalized) or at the beginning of a sentence (in which undefined should be capitalized) it should be all lowercase.

I think we could get away with making it a named term with a specific definition. Perhaps we could even link to some documentation with further description of what Undefined Behavior does and doesn't mean.
So do you think this is something that should be capitalized everywhere, and linked back to a document with a definition?
Definitely the latter, and I think the former would help.
So there is this page, which talks about UB but doesn't really give it a definition: https://doc.rust-lang.org/reference/behavior-considered-undefined.html
Could also maybe link to it in the glossary: https://doc.rust-lang.org/reference/glossary.html#undefined-behavior
There is a little inconsistency out in the world, but I think the lowercase form is predominant in the language specs I've seen.
I agree it should be lowercase, as that seems a lot more common. So lowercase + link - or lowercase without a link?
As for links, I think it depends on the scenario, but generally in the standard library I would lean towards linking it to https://doc.rust-lang.org/reference/behavior-considered-undefined.html

I think it's like "Licensor" or "Work" in https://opensource.org/licenses/Apache-2.0 -- a reference to a well-defined term that wouldn't normally be capitalized but is to emphasize the particular meaning.
Is there any other example of this that isn't part of a license?

that's inherited from legalese

In legal English, defined terms that refer to a specific entity, such as "Tenant" and "Lessor", are often capitalized. More specifically, in legal documents, terms which are formally defined elsewhere in the document or a related document (often in a schedule of definitions) are capitalized to indicate that that is the case, and may be several words long, e.g. "the Second Subsidiary Claimant", "the Agreed Conditional Release Date".
I personally don't think we should apply that rule in this case, as I don't think we do that anywhere else in the codebase
it's tricky, because people approach this with some intuitive idea of what "undefined behavior" means, which often doesn't align with the formal term
Do you feel like "undefined behavior" with a link to the documentation is sufficient?

Notably, my recollection is that Ralf only wants things defined to be UB to be UB, which makes the term "Undefined Behaviour" different from one would get from just combining "undefined"+"behaviour". So I think it's worth emphasizing Terms of Art somehow -- the same way that if someone says sound in rust there are very specific implications of the meaning.
Might be worth considering that the glossary currently does not capitalize it: https://doc.rust-lang.org/reference/glossary.html#undefined-behavior
that glossary entry is actually a lot looser than I would like
"Compile-time or run-time behavior that is not specified."
that's not the same as formal UB
Was trying to look up to see if there is a more formal definition that Clang/LLVM uses but couldn't actually find anything
https://rust-lang.github.io/unsafe-code-guidelines/glossary.html#undefined-behavior might be helpful. (And that page seems to follow the "Undefined Behavior is always capitalized" convention.)

So seems to me there are two ways to go about making this more clear:

Option 1:

  1. Update the Rust glossary with a better version of undefined behavior from the unsafe book
  2. Link all uses of undefined behavior to that glossary
  3. Change the capitalization to lowercase across the board

Option 2:

  1. Update the Rust glossary with a better version of undefined behavior from the unsafe book
  2. When refering to defined undefined behavior, capitilize it and link it to the glossary
  3. Otherwise, make it lowercase and don't(?) link it back

What do ya'll think?
For opt2.3, I'd prefer to find a different term in those cases to avoid confusion
let "undefined behavior" and "behavior is undefined" have the formal meaning across the board
Makes sense
